column5: After 50 years of fishing in Ontario I finally caught a pike exceeding 40". It was 42" caught from Melchett Lake Ontario on a jig, twister tail, and no leader. Released fish to get bigger. My old mind started asking just how old might this fish be. Contacted Ministry in Ontario and they came back the following. A 42" pike caught in lakes North of Nakina would be approximate 14 years old. If lake has lake trout then the pike would grow faster.
Thanks for that info! I have always wondered the exact same thing!Sent from my SCH-I535 using Tapatalk

Here's a nice chart for you & others to enjoy:http://www.wildernessisland.com/Wall...p#.U6ckk7HPx8sI printed one out & had it laminated & thumb tacked it in the fish cleaning hut at the lodge we go to in Ontario.Fish
Very interesting info. More evidence to show the big ones need to be released. Thanks for sharing, gentlemen.
Definitely release large fish. If you must have a wall hanger. Photo, measure and get a replica.

Really cool to see how old these fish are. Thanks for the chart. Caught the second biggest northern of my life on my trip to Northern Ontario two weeks ago. 39 3/4"! Fought like crazy. I just couldn't seem to stretch it to a 40"! My only northern above 40" was a 44" back in 2002! What a fish. BTW, both were released. I hope my kids/grandkids get a shot at them!
how fast fisheries react to catch and release,,,,,,,,,,,,,,CPR Catch...Photo..Release 99.99% of the time,,,,,cant pass on a nice walleye or pike fillet once in awhile
